title: Is it right to say or write sentences like 'I am student' or 'she is teacher'? - Quora

response.answer_text: Like Spanish, English does not need an article for nationality or religion. “She is American.”“He is Christian.” Unlike Spanish, English does need an article for professions. “He is a teacher.”“She is an engineer.”“I am a gardener.”

No, it’s not correct. It is missing the article before the noun. It’s a common mistake that English speakers will hear right away. So, this is correct: “I am a student.”“She is a teacher.” However, please note that in the plural, the article is not needed: “We are students. They are teachers.”Also correct in the singular: I am the student (a particular one) and she is the teacher (perhaps clarifying that she is THE teacher, and not the student, or another person or profession.)
